 I. BACKGROUND A. BANK PRE-WAR INVOLVEMENT IN ENERGY 1. The Bank has been heavily involved in the energy sector in Bosnia and Herzegovina in the past, notably in electric power, petroleum and natural gas. Power sector projects, which benefitted partly or exclusively BH included the Third Power Loan (Loan 386-YU; US$75 million; 1972) and the Fourth Power Loan (Loan 1469-YU; US80 million; 1977), both of which helped finance the development -of SFRY's interconnected power system; the Fifth Power Project (Loan 1561-YU; US$73 million; 1978) was for development of the hydro power plants on the middle Neretva River; the Sixth Power Project (Loan 1561-1-YU; US$61 million; 1983) was for construction of the Mostar dam; the Seventh Power Project (Loan 2338-YU; US$120 million; 1984) financed SFRY's energy management system; and the Eighth Power Project was for the Visegrad hydro power plant (Loan 2527-YU; US$125 million; 1985). In the petroleum sector the Bank financed the First Petroleum Project (Loan 2597-YU; US$92.5 million; 1985) for development of indigenous energy resources. In the gas sector the Bank financed the Sarajevo Air Pollution Control Project (Loan 1264-YU; US$38 million; 1975). An Emergency District Heating Reconstruction Project was approved by the Bank's Board of Directors on May 14, 1996 (Credit TF024034; US$20 million). The Bank did not previously finance projects in the coal sector in BH. B. NATURAL GAS 2. Background. The gas system in BH was developed starting in 1975 under the Bank's Sarajevo Air Pollution Control Project (Loan 1264-YU). Russian gas is supplied via Hungary and Serbia and enters BH at Zvornik, in Republika Srpska. As of 1992 the gas supply network consisted of 190 km of transmission mains and offtake pipes, running from Zvornik to the Sarajevo area via Semizovac and from the latter to Zenica. Consumption peaked in 1990 with 610 million cubic meters, constituting 8% of the total energy consumption in BH. Within Sarajevo, there were 15,000 household connections and all major boilers of the city's district heating network had been converted from coal to gas-firing. Gas imports for BH are metered at the Ukraine/Hungarian border (Beregov, the contractual point of delivery of the gas) and from there they are transported through the Hungarian and Serb transmission systems to Zvornik. The cost of transporting the gas from Beregov to BH is equivalent to about 35% of the contracted gas volume. The gas was imported under a contract between Energopetrol, a state-owned oil and gas company, and Gazexport, the export branch of Russia's Gazprom. Within BH, gas transmission and distribution was (and is) the responsibility of Sarajevogas.
 - 2 - 3. Current Situation. At the beginning of the war gas supply coming into Sarajevo was reduced to such an extent that gas use for industry and much of the district heating became impossible. With the additional destruction of part of the district heating system in Sarajevo early on and given a sharp reduction of electricity generation in BH, gas suddenly assumed major importance for the inhabitants of Sarajevo as a means to stay warm and to cook. Many improvised connections and appliances were made, which has often led to explosions and highly inefficient gas use. As of the end of 1995, the total number of household connections in all of Sarajevo was estimated at around 85,000. Gas consumption now constitutes about 70% of all energy consumption in Sarajevo and it is the basic heating and cooking fuel for the city's remaining 300,000 inhabitants. 4. Debt to Gazexport. While the gas supply from Semizovac to Zenica (the entire western branch of the transmission system, affecting several major industries along that line) was shut off during the war. some gas was allowed to come into Sarajevo. In exchange, gas was allowed to go to Belgrade and to the Bosnian Serbs. The total debt for gas supplied by Gazexport was US$105 million as of October 12, 1995. Of this total, GBH claims that only about 30% is owed by it for the supply of gas to the Bosnian part of Sarajevo. The new agreement signed between Gazexport and Energopetrol calls for delivery at Beregov of specified quantities of gas for both the Federation and the Republika Srpska at US$80 per 1,000 m3. Since then, most supplies have been paid for and efforts are underway to come to a permanent solution for full payment of current gas consumption. 5. Sector Strategy. The proposed sector strategy would be to: (i) seek partial donor funding for the next three years of gas consumption; (ii) reconfigure the gas network and restore safe service to acceptable levels; (iii) ensure demand management through disconnection of consumers that can be reconnected to the district heating system, introduction of energy efficient appliances, and cost recovery, (iv) strengthen the sector enticy; and (v) settle past debts to Gazexport. An Emergency Gas System Project is expected to be presented to the Board in FY97. C. DISTRICT HEATING 6. Background. In 1991 BH had district heating (DH) systems in most major towns and cities with a population in excess of about 25,000 inhabitants. The systems were generally run by municipally-owned district heating enterprises (DHEs). Cogeneration was provided only by the combined heat and power plants in Tuzla and Kakanj as well as by local industries; the remaining heat was generated by local heat-only boilers. Already prior to the war, some efforts had been made to start converting coal-fired boilers to gas or oil firing, notably in Sarajevo. DH systems throughout BH served 120,000 customers, equivalent to 450,000 inhabitants or 10% of the total population. The Sarajevo DH system was the country's largest, serving about 180,000 inhabitants or 45% of the population of Sarajevo. All DH systems delivered mostly heat only and provided domestic hot water only to a small percentage of consumers. Heat prices were set locally and were not uniform nationwide. Subsidies for heat and hot water consumption were provided
 based on income level from local tax proceeds. The average subsidy was US$100 per annum, compared to an average annual heat bill of about US$370 per consumer. 7. Current Situation. Currently, the DH systems in Sarajevo, Banja Luka, Bihac and Mostar are only partly operational. In Sarajevo the system has been damaged due to shelling and freezing of the pipes in the network; building internal heating installations in residential dwellings (pipes, radiators and valves) have incurred substantial damage, also due to the rusting associated with non-usage of the system. In Banja Luka most of the damage is related to non-usage of the system due to lack of fuel, and associated rusting and freezing. In all cities, lack of maintenance due to the absence of spare parts has been significant and further aggravated the problems. 8. Sector Strategy. The proposed sector strategy would be to: (i) restore urban district heating services to adequate levels as soon as possible, disconnect previously serviced flats from the gas system (in Sarajevo) and reduce fuel wood consumption (in Banja Luka); (ii) rehabilitate building internal heating installations; (iii) strengthen sector institutions and increase cost recovery; and (iv) undertake master plan studies to prepare plans for the optimal configuration of each city's future heating system. An Emergency District Heating Reconstruction Project was approved by the Board of Directors on May 14, 1996. D. ELECTRIC POWER 9. Background. In 1990 BH produced 13,090 Gigawatt hours (GWh) of electricity from generating plants located on its territory. Electricity consumption was 11,181 GWh. The system comprised 13 hydro power plants with a total capacity of 2,034 Megawatt (MW) and an average output of 6,922 GWh/year, and 12 thermal power plants with a total capacity of 1,957 Megawatt (MW) and an output of 10,675 GWh in 1990. The thermal power plants were coal and lignite fired, with the fuel coming from mines within BH. EPBiH was responsible for operating its own system and meeting local demand. However, being part of the former Yugoslav network, the 400 kV power grid in BH was controlled by JUGEL's dispatching center in Belgrade. Power exchanges with neighboring countries were also controlled by JUGEL. 10. The BH power system was operated by Elektroprivreda Bosne i Hercegovine (EPBiH) and consists of generation, transmission and distribution facilities interconnected and operated at 400, 220, 110, 35, 20, 10 and 0.4 kV voltage levels. Transmission voltages are 110 kV and higher; distribution voltages are 35 kV and lower. Total length of the transmission lines was about 5,400 km and of the distribution lines 92,000 km. Transmission and distribution transformer capacity was about 15,300 MVA. The backbone of the interconnected transmission system is a 400 kV network (with a transmission line length of about 800 km and with 8 substations), which is interconnected with Croatia, Montenegro and Serbia. The 400 kV transmission line section of Trebinje- Gacko-Mostar forms part of the southern main line interconnecting the member countries of SUDEL (Austria, Italy, Greece, Former Yugoslavia) and UCPTE.
 11. Current Situation. War damage to the BH power system started in 1991 with destruction of transmission facilities and interconnection lines to neighboring countries and UCPTE and thereafter spread to large parts of the generation, transmission and distribution systems. A description of the damage follows: Generation: Installed capacity in the Federation area was 2,574 MW (or 65% of the total installed capacity in BiH) and 49% of its generating capacity is currently damaged. The following hydropower plants on the Neretva River are damaged or out of operation for other reasons: Jablanica (6x25 MW); Grabovica (2x57 MW); Salakovac (3x70 MW); Mostar (3x25 MW); and the Rama plant on the Rama river (2x80 MW). The Tuzla (779 MW) and Kakanj (578 MW) thermal power plants also suffered extensive damage. The condition of the hydro power plants on the Trebisnjica River (2x54 MW, lx60 MW, 2 x 215 MW, and lx8 MW) and on the Drina River (3x105 MW), and the Ugljevik (1x300 MW) and Gracko (1x300 MW) thermal power plants has seriously deteriorated due to lack of maintenance as a result of the war. In 1994, generation of the major power plants in the Federation area was only 1,744 GWh (41% of the total generation in BiH). Transmission: About 60% of the transmission network and control system are seriously damaged. Many transformer stations, including all eight 400 kV transformer substations, civil works, telecommunications and maintenance equipment are seriously damaged or destroyed. The interconnection with SUIDEL and UCPTE has been interrupted, as well as the connection of Greece with SUDEL through the 400 kV line through Mostar. Distribution: The distribution network is largely destroyed. During the first half of 1994 residential consumers in the Federation area received only 4-6 hours of electricity per day. The Government introduced rationing of electricity in 1995. Residential consumers were allowed a maximum of 180 kWh/month/household in May 1995. 12. Sector Strategy. The proposed sector strategy would be to: (i) restore service to acceptable levels; (ii) reconfigure the electric power network to optimize the system, taking into account BH's need for significant independence from the SFRY's network and its security of supply, (iii) improve sector finances by improving billing and collections and gradually revising the tariff structure and levels to reflect supply costs for each category of consumers; and (iv) restructure the sector by introducing a sector structure and regulatory framework that would facilitate attracting potential investors E. COAL 13. Background. In the 1980's the coal rnines in BH produced annually about 18 million tons of coal, of which 10 rnillion tons of brown coal and 8 million tons of lignite. Their brown coal output accounted for about 80% of total SFRY production, lignite for only 15%. Production was concentrated in areas near Tuzla and Zenica in both open pit
 - 5 - as well as underground mines. In addition, two mines in the Republika Srpska were important: Ugljevik (brown coal) and Gracko (lignite). About half of the production originated from surface mines and the other half from underground mines. BH's proven reserves of coal are about 1.6 billion tons. More than 80% of BH's total production was used for electric power generation and the remaining 20% for industrial and household uses. 14. Current Situation. Coal production dropped to 1.5 million tons in 1994, i.e. less than 10% of the pre-war level. The coal mines in the Federation have been grouped into two principal companies: the Tuzla Coal Mines and the Central Bosnia Coal Mines, which supply thermal power plants. The Ugljevik Coal Mine is an important and relatively modern surface mine in Republika Srpska. Much of the mobile mining equipment has been cannibalized beyond repair. Some newer mobile equipment had to be turned over to the army or just disappeared. There is an acute lack of critical materials such as fuel, tires and spare parts. 15. Despite the drastic drop in production, no efforts were made to concentrate production in a few large and economic mines. The number of people employed has decreased from 26,000 to about 7,000. Since production declined much faster, productivity is now among the lowest in the world. Present production costs appear to be at or above the world market level of coal prices adjusted for quality and are higher than sales prices, which are set by the State. To ensure future financial viability, coal mining enterprises need to close uneconomic capacity. 16. Sector Strategy. The proposed sector strategy would be to: (i) determine priority actions for the lowest cost mines whose output is competitive with imports; (ii) restore output of the lowest-cost mines to minimum acceptable levels (para 24 (j)); and (iii) restructure the coal industry, including closing uneconomic mining capacity and privatizing services and the most efficient mines wherever possible I. BANK RESPONSE AND STRATEGY 17. The conclusion of the Dayton-Paris Peace Agreement in December 1995 ended Europe's most destructive war in the last fifty years. The war has shattered the economy and brought productive activity almost to a standstill. The country's pre-war GDP of about US$9 billion has shrunk to about US$2 billion, and its per-capita GDP declined from about US$1900 to about US$500. The majority of the 900,000 workers employed in 1991 are currently still unemployed. Wages and salariesare low. Pensions are paid but at low levels. Many people still receive some form of humanitarian assistance. At least 200- 250,000 people are dead or missing, and over 1 million people left the country. In addition, there are about 1.5 million displaced people in the country, many of whom live in temporary shelters. Enormous damage has been inflicted on the country's physical
 - 6 - infrastructure, including energy. Direct war damages are huge, probably in the range of US$15-20 billion. Indirect damage due to lack of maintenance and corrosion accounts for many more billions of dollars of losses. A. SECTOR RECONSTRUCTION PROGRAM 18. A reconstruction and rehabilitation program for the combined energy sectors of BH of about US$900 million has been prepared as part of the US$5.1 billion reconstruction program for all sectors, over 3-4 years, which the Bank has helped to develop in a joint effort with the country and the donor community. The energy sector program calls for a major effort to restore destroyed, damaged and forcibly neglected equipment and to bring service back as soon as possible to near pre-war levels. The proposed project will be the second major element in this program, following the Emergency District Heating Reconstruction Project (Credit TF 024034 of US$20 million; May 1996). It aims to ensure restoration of reliable and continuous electricity supply to a number of major cities and industries. The financing of some urgently needed equipment for the power sector is already included under the Bank's Emergency Recovery Project. 19. A third emergency project in the energy sector planned for FY97 is the Emergency Gas System Reconstruction Project, which focuses mostly on Sarajevo. Projects with a medium term perspective would deal with further reconstruction and rehabilitation of the various energy sectors and would address broader policy issues such as the sector's regulatory framework, energy pricing, sector restructuring, and eventual privatization in more detail. B. WORLD BANK STRATEGY AND PROGRAMS IN BOSNIA AND HERZEGOVINA 20. On April 1, 1996 BH fulfilled the conditions of succession to the Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia's membership in the Bank, IDA and IFC. Membership is retroactive to February 25, 1993. 21. Since early 1995, the Bank Group has been deeply involved in developing a donor- funded reconstruction program for BH. A joint mission of the Bank, IMF, EU and EBRD in late 1995 resulted in the proposed Priority Reconstruction Program which was first presented to a donors' meeting, co-sponsored by the Bank and the EU in Brussels, a week after the signing of the Paris/Dayton Peace Agreement. This meeting led to donor commitments of about US$600 million for immediate reconstruction activities. A second donors' conference, again co-chaired by the Bank and the EU, was held in mid-April, 1996 and resulted in additional donor pledges in the order of US$1.2 billion for financing priority reconstruction activities during 1996. 22. The Bank has been following a two-track assistance strategy, which seeks to leverage its limited resources with significant resource transfer from donors. First, before
 - 7 - arrears resolution, the Bank supported selected immediate assistance programs through a special Trust Fund for Reconstruction of Bosnia and Herzegovina (TFBH) which is providing US$125 million on concessional terms equivalent to those offered by IDA, as well as an additional US$25 million in grant funds. Seven emergency operations, committing the entire US$150 million, have been approved under the TFBH: an Emergency Recovery Project; a Water, Sanitation, and Solid Waste Urgent Works Project; an Emergency Farm Reconstruction Project; an Emergency Transport Project; an Emergency District Heating Reconstruction Project; an Emergency Education Reconstruction Project and a War Victims Rehabilitation Project. Second, following arrears resolution (which was made possible by the effectiveness of the Consolidation Loan package on June 14, 1996), while the Bank will continue to focus on supporting the implementation of the reconstruction program, its assistance program will be broadened to include support for the initial phase of the Government's macroeconomic and institutional reforms. In the area of reconstruction, Bank assistance will focus on employment generation and housing, both needed to facilitate the reintegration of demobilized soldiers and the return of refugees, as well as on continued support for the rehabilitation of infrastructure and clearance of landmines. III. THE PROJECT A. PROJECT OBJECTIVES 23. The objectives of the project would be to: (i) restore electricity service to acceptable levels in major cities and for vital industries. Initial reconstruction would target mainly critical power plants (including notably cogeneration plants), principal substations and major transmission lines; (ii) increase coal production in the most efficient mines to supply the fuel necessary for the cogeneration and power-only thermal plants; (iii) reconfigure the electric power network, taking into account BH's need for significant independence from Belgrade and security of electricity supply, (iv) enhance the sector's institutional capacity and improve its finances; and (v) support sector restructuring. In addition, the project would establish a procurement monitoring and audit unit for all Bank/IDA financed, cofinanced or administered projects. B. PROJECT DESCRIPTION 24. The proposed project has electric power generation, transmission and distribution components, an associated coal mining component and, in addition, a procurement monitoring and audit unit component. The electric power component of the project is

Rehabilitation and maintenance of hydro plant at: (i) Jablanica (4x25 MW); (ii) Grabovica (2x57 MW); (iii) Mostar (3x25 MW); and (iv) Jajce I (2x25 MW). The project would restore the plants to normal operating condition; b) Rehabilitation of Thermal Power Stations. This would cover the most urgent reconstruction needs of the distribution networks in the districts of Sarajevo, Tuzla, Zenica, Mostar, Doboj, Bihac, Grahovo, G. Vakuf, Maglaj, Banja Luka, Bijeljina, Pale, Trebinje, Gorazde, Foca, Kopaci, Glamoc and Jajce; e) Repair of Communication and System Control. The system control and communication system has been extensively damaged. To retain control of the power system, the microwave link Sarajevo-Kakanj and the Sarajevo Load Dispatch Center have to be urgently repaired, f) Purchase of Service Vehicles. Most of EPBiH's service vehicles were damaged during the war. The project would supply vehicles for generation, transmission and distributions maintenance, and for billing and collection services; g) Purchase of Spare Parts. The spare parts to be ordered are primarily for maintenance of existing generation plants and for the transmission and distribution systems. This includes the reestablishment of sufficient stock levels with a minimum inventory level of two years at the time of project completion; h) Technical Assistance comprises engineering and consultants services as follows: (i) engineering services for preparation of bidding documents, technical approvals of vender offers, drawings and designs, construction supervision, inspection and expediting, and general assistance to the electric utilities in Bosnia and Herzegovina. It will comprise international power experts' services and a large number of man-months of local engineering consultants' services

A project management support component is included for partial repair of office facilities and the supply of basic office equipment for the Project Implementation Unit of EPBiH; j) Associated Coal Mines. The emergency rehabilitation of selected economically viable coal mines (the Dubrave, Sikylje and Banovici surface mines, and the Mramor underground mine of the Tuzla Mining Company, the Vrtliste surface mine and Breza underground mine at Kakanj of the Central Bosnia Mining Company, and the Ugljevik surface mine at Ugljevik) focuses on meeting the coal supply needs of the Tuzla, Kakanj and Ugljevik thermal power plants. To meet the power plants' requirements, urgent rehabilitation of these specific coal mines is required. The rehabilitation would mainly consist of: (i) supply of consumable materials, such as tires, conveyor belts, cable and spare parts for the existing equipment; (ii) replacement of key smaller equipment damaged beyond repair, but crucial to operation and maintenance; (iii) overhaul of major production equipment; and (iv) provision of consultants' services to assist the Government in preparing a coal sector restructuring program (Attachment 2.1); and k) Procurement Monitoring and Audit Unit. To optimize the benefits of the ongoing Emergency Reconstruction Program and to promote mobilization of additional resources from abroad, the objectives of efficiency and economy should be adhered to at all times. This objective would be achieved by the creation of a Procurement Monitoring and Auditing Unit (PMAU) that ensures transparency of procurement process in all Government-executed projects, regardless of the source of their financing. The Government is expected to establish formally such a PMAU not later than October 31,1996. 25. Because of the urgency of establishing an effective and well functioning procurement monitoring and auditing system as soon as possible, an interim arrangement for one year, starting September 1, 1996 would entrust this function to an experienced and reputable international firm. During the first year the PMAU consultants would: (a) monitor at least one full cycle of procurement and disbursement transactions carried-out by each executing agency (PIU) for Bank/IDA financed or administered projects. The selection of the transactions at their different stages of processing would be made randomly. Monitoring of additional contracts or steps of processing for the same project will be necessary only in cases of observed important deficiencies in procurement practices; (b) carry out ex-post annual procurement audits for all projects financed by the Bank up to September 1, 1996; (c) prepare specific audits as requested by Government or by the Bank as needed; (d) submit findings according to a pre-agreed time table to the head of the executing agency, the government and the Bank for all the audits referred to above and according to a pre-agreed schedule, including recommendations for improvements or adjustments; (e) design a monitoring and auditing system with

C. SECTOR RESTRUCTURING 26. There are today, de facto, three entities in the power sector in BH: (i) EPBiH; (ii) Elektroprivreda Herzeg-Bosna, operating in the Croat areas of the Federation and which is not integrated with the Croatian power entity; and (iii) Elektroprivreda Republika Srpska, operating in the Republika Srpska and which exchanges power with Serbia. Because the core of the BH electricity system (almost 50% of all installed capacity, containing both hydro as well as thermal power plants) is managed by EPBiH, IDA would focus its funding on the EPBiH-managed part of the system, while the EU, the EBRD and some other donors would primarily focus on distribution and generation in BH. 27. While the power system may be too small to enable effective competition, measures can and should be taken to introduce a sector structure that would facilitate attracting potential investors as follows: a) In a first stage, generation could be separated from transmission and distribution and broken down in several generating companies, each operating on a commercial basis; the transmission system could be unified under a single authority to ensure the optimization of power transmission and permit effective power trading as well as system stabilization. Distribution enterprises could be organized on a local basis. As part of a proposed power sector restructuring study an Energy Law should be prepared (and eventually passed), under which a Regulatory Authority should be set up to regulate power prices and to ensure third party access to the transmission system. b) In a second stage, once the Regulatory Authority has been established and operates with reasonable autonomy, the generation and distribution companies could be partially or totally privatized. The transmission entity could eventually be considered for privatization after the new ownership arrangements in the generation and distribution segments have stabilized. Regardless of whether or not the transmission entity is privatized, the Energy Law should allow for third party access. Consultants services will be provided under the proposed project to assist in carrying out the electricity sector restructuring study. D. COST ESTIMATE 28. Cost Structure. Fuel (coal and oil) costs account for around 25% of EPBiH's total operating expenses. EPBiH purchases its coal from domestic coal mines; costs per gigajoule are high in relation to international standards but are expected to improve when the coal mines are restructured. Operating and maintenance costs are at acceptable levels, however, this is aided by the depressed levels of wages and salaries as well as the lower than normal staff level. Tariffs. Considering the difficult situation in the war period, tariffs were maintained at fairly high levels of about US$0.052 per kWh on average in 1995. However, these levels do not fully cover costs. Moreover, the structure is distorted in favor of households who, at only about US$0.024 per kWh, are charged far less than the full cost of providing electricity; this encourages uneconomic use, including for space heatinig. On the other hand, industries and high voltage users pay a tariff that may exceed the effective cost. Therefore, the tariff structure should be revised to reflect the differentials in supply costs for different groups of customers. EPBiH should consider introducing an interim tariff of about US$0.057 per kWh for consumption in excess of 150 kWh per month per household starting in 1997, in order to discourage space heating with electricity, as opposed to with district heating or gas. Furthermore, tariff levels in general would need to be raised progressively, first to permit adequate internal generation of funds to cover EPBiH's expenditures and provide modest cash balances, and later to provide full cost coverage as EPBiH undertakes further necessary efficiency-improving investments. 51. doc.abstracts: The objectives of the Emergency Electric Power Reconstruction Project are to: a) restore electricity service to acceptable levels targeting critical power plants, principal substations and major transmission lines; b) increase coal production in the most efficient mines; c) reconfigure the electric power network; d) enhance the sector's institutional capacity and improve its finances; and e) support sector restructuring. The projects' components consist of: a) electric power generation by rehabilitation of hydro and thermal power plants; reconstruction of distribution networks, transmission lines, and substations; and the purchase of service vehicles and spare parts; b) transmission and distribution of power; c) associated coal mines; and d) a procurement monitoring and audit unit component.
